content.description: Pulling the roof is the crux.
content.protection: The first half of the route is bolted, bring 3 draws.  The top half is trad, beginning at the roof and following the natural weaknesses to the anchor.  A hand sized cam, 2.5 friend or no. 1 Camalot, protects the roof nicely, large or midsized nuts finish the job.
content.location: Follow bolts and natural weakness starting at far right of wall and below the start level of Buckets for Buckey.

content.description: A nice trad line just right of Bangkok.  Follows natural weakness/crack  through a small bulge.  Look for small hidden pockets.
content.protection: Small nuts and tcu's work fine.
content.location: It's an obvious natural line on the right side of the wall.  See the topo photo.  Shares an anchor with Syd Barrett's Corner.

content.description: Bangkok is the third route from the left at the Upper Utah Wall.  It's a pretty fun and consistent climb that has good edging and some slabby feet. On my way to the third bolt, I found it easier to just make another move or two and clip the bolt than waste time and energy trying to wiggle a cam in the shallow, horizontal cracks.  You might deck if you fell pulling rope, though.
content.protection: Three bolts and anchors.  You might want a small cam to protect between bolts two and three.

content.description: Like most routes on this wall, most of the difficulties seem to be near the bottom.  A long reach for a side-pull with my right hand seemed to be the crux, just after the first bolt.
content.location: Leftmost bolted line, shares anchor with 911

content.description: Good continuous climbing on vertical face.
